questions.text: A patient with ear wax underwent syringing. During syringing, patient developed syncopal episode. Stimulation of which nerve is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Arnold's nerve
Sol :  
•	The nerve responsible for a vasovagal attack during syringing of the ear is Arnold nerve branch of vagus nerve. 
•	Stimulation of the vagus nerve, such as during syringing of the ear, can cause a decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, leading to a vasovagal attack.

questions.text: Which of the following is the safe limit of noise levels in a city
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

45 dB
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
•	Noise travels through the air. Noise is measured in decibels.
•	Experts believe that continuous noise levels in excess of 90 decibels can cause loss of hearing and irreversible changes in nervous systems.
•	The World Health Organization [WHO] has fixed 45 decibels as the safe noise level for a city.

questions.text: A 30- year old woman with family history of hearing loss from her mother's side developed hearing problem dur­ing pregnancy. Hearing loss is bilateral, slowly progres­sive, Pure tone audiometry shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Otosclerosis
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
•	Otosclerosis is traditionally diagnosed by characteristic clinical findings, which include progressive conductive hearing loss, a normal tympanic membrane, and no evidence of middle ear inflammation. The cochlear promontory may have a faint pink tinge reflecting the vascularity of the lesion, referred to as the Schwartze sign.
•	Conductive hearing loss is usually secondary to impingement of abnormal bone on the stapes footplate. This involvement of the oval window forms the basis of the name fenestral otosclerosis.
•	The most common location of involvement of otosclerosis is the bone just anterior to the oval window at a small cleft known as the fissula ante fenestram.
•	The fissula is a thin fold of connective tissue extending through the endochondral layer, approximately between the oval window and the cochleariform process, where the tensor tympani tendon turns laterally toward the malleus.
•	As 2 kHz is the resonant frequency of the ossicular chain, the largest increase in bone conduction threshold (around 15 dB) occurs at this frequency – the resultant notch is called 
•	Carhart's notch and is a useful clinical marker for medial ossicular-chain fixation.

questions.text: Identify the hearing Aid shown in the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) CIC Ref: Read the text below Sol:

questions.text: Which of the following is not canal wall down (CWD) mastoidectomy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Combined approach tympanoplasty
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
Canal wall down (CWD) procedures
•	Modified radical mastoidectomy
•	Radical mastoidectomy
•	Atticotomy	
Canal wall up  (CWU) procedures
•	Cortical mastoidectomy ( schwartz operation)
•	Combined approach tympanoplasty

questions.text: A congenitally deaf child on radiological evaluation of cochlea and brain with MRI has been found to having absent cochlea. What is the best method of hearing rehabilitation in this case.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Auditory brain stem implant surgery
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
•	Brain stem implant is placed on lateral recess of 4th ventricle near cochlear nucleus for stimulation. 
•	The indications are- NF-2 cases with bilateral acoustic neuromas, congenital absence of VIII nerve, cochlear aplasia(Michel’s)

choices.text: Right Conductive Deafness and Left Sensorineural Deafness.
Right Conductive Deafness and Left Conductive Deafness.
Right Sensorineural Deafness and Left Conductive Deafness.
Right Sensorineural Deafness and Left Sensorineural Deafness.

questions.text: Comment on the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right Sensorineural Deafness and Left Sensorineural Deafness
Reference – Read the text below
Sol : 
Rinne Test:
Air conduction (AC) of the ear is compared with its bone conduction (BC)
Positive Rinne Test:
AC > BC
Seen in normal persons or those having sensory-neural deafness
Negative Rinne Test:
BC > AC
Seen in conductive deafness
Important point:
A negative Rinne indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 15-20 db.
False negative Rinne test is seen in severe unilateral sensory-neural hearing loss

questions.text: A 30 year old male is having Attic cholesteatoma of left ear with extradural abscess. Which of the following will be the operation of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Canal wall down mastoidectomy
Ref: Read the text below
Sol : 
•	Attic cholesteatoma is an indication for modified radical mastoidectomy. (Canal wall down mastoidectomy)

questions.text: Identify the incision shown the given image ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Wilde’s incision
Reference – Read the text below
Sol : 
•	Wilde's incision – This post-aural incision is used for a variant mastoiditis drainage, and was named after Sir William Wilde, an ENT surgeon in Dubli
•	Tympanomeatal flap is raised to expose the middle ear in endomeatal approach
•	Rosen’s incision is used in the endomeatal approach for stapedectomy
•	It is also used for exploratory tympanotomy.

questions.text: Given finding is highly suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acoustic neuroma 
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:  
•	The configuration of the mass is of an ‘ice cream’ cone. 
•	Vestibular schwannoma is a benign tumor of glial cell origin.
•	It most commonly arises from the vestibular branch of the 8th cranial nerve.
•	It is a cause of unilateral sensorineural hearing loss in adults.
•	If bilateral, the patient most likely has neurofibromatosis Type 2.
•	Important other masses occurring at the CP angle, include epidermoid cyst, pseudo tumor, metastases and lymphoma.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic consults a physician because of severe and persistent earache. Otoscopic examination demonstrates foul-smelling purulent otorrhea and a red mass lesion of the external ear canal. Biopsy of the mass demonstrates granulation tissue rather than tumor. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pseudomonas aeruginosa 
Sol:

•	External otitis, or infection of the external ear canal, can be caused by a variety of organisms, notably including Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Proteus vulgaris, and Staphylococcus aureus. There is, however, a severe subtype of external otitis, malignant external otitis, of which you should be aware. This form is specifically caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and tends to affect elderly diabetics and AIDS patients, causing the findings illustrated in the question stem. It is particularly worrisome both because the Pseudomonas organism is so tissue destructive and because it is often highly resistant to most intravenous antibiotics. (Consult your local microbiology or pharmacology departments for advice about local sensitivities if you encounter the condition.) Complications can be devastating, including deafness, facial nerve paralysis, osteomyelitis, and meningitis. 
•	Escherichia coli can cause both external otitis and acute otitis media, but does not usually cause malignant external otitis. 
•	Haemophilus influenza is an important cause of acute otitis media. 
Proteus vulgaris can cause external otitis, but does not usually cause the malignant form.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Type B Curve

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Entire face on the same side is paralysed

questions.text: Function of utricle and saccule is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Linear motion
Sol :  

•	There are two sets of end organs in the inner ear, or labyrinth: the semicircular canals, which respond to rotational movements (angular acceleration); and the utricle and saccule within the vestibule, which respond to changes in the position of the head with respect to gravity (linear acceleration).

questions.text: Battle sign is defined as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ecchymosis on Mastoid

Sol : 

Battle’s sign appears as a large bruise that extends across the entire backside of your ear, and it may also extend out to the upper part of your neck.

questions.text: A 6 year old child with the history of mouth breathing, high arched palate, failure to thrive and hearing loss . Which of the following will be best management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion
Sol :  

•	This child is probably suffering from adenotonsillar hypertrophy which is causing recurrent respiratory tract infection and mouth breathing. 
•	Hypertrophied adenoids/tonsils might have led to Eustachian tube blockade with a resultant SOM which explains decreased hearing. 
•	So the treatment is Myringotomy with grommet insertion along with Adeno-tonsillectomy in the same sitting.
•	Myringoplasty is the surgical repair of TM and is done in CSOM.

questions.text: A patient presents to ENT OPD with pulsatile tinnitus,reddish mass behind tympanic membrane. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glomus tumour
Sol :  

                          Glomus Tumors (Paragangliomas, Chemodectomas)
Glomus Tumor: slow growing, benign tumor although locally destructive (expansive, bone eroding) of the chemoreceptive cells (paraganglion cells, neural crest in origin) distributed along parasympathetic nerves in the base of skull, neck, and chest
• Most common benign tumor of the temporal bone of adults (rare in pediatrics)
Glomus Vagale: arise from paraganglia around the vagus nerve at the base of skull
• SSx: pulsatile tinnitus (most common symptom), hearing loss, cranial nerve palsies, aural discharge, otalgia, dizziness (invasion of the labyrinth), reddish middle ear mass, BROWN’S SIGN (BLANCHING OF THE TM WITH POSITIVE PRESSURE)
• Rx: surgical resection after preoperative embolization or primary
radiation therapy for nonoperable candidates, advanced tumors, or presence of residual disease

questions.text: A patient presented with pain around mastoid, and positive reservoir sign. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mastoiditis
Sol :  

Mastoiditis Symptoms
•	Pain behind the ear seen
•	Fever: Persistence of fever in otitis media → resemble development of mastoiditis
•	Ear discharge - profuse
Signs
•	Ear Discharge - mucopurulent profuse
•	Mastoid tenderness
•	Mastoid swelling
•	Reservoir sign - meatus immediately fills with pus after it has been mopped out
•	Sagging of posterosuperior wall
•	Perforation of tympanic
•	membrane small pertora at para tensa
•	Hearing loss - conductive type hearing loss
Treatment
•	Hospitalize the patient
•	Antibiotics Amoxicillin
•	Myringotonny
•	Cortical Mastoidectomy in these cases

questions.text: A young child presented with lower lip swelling. Upon lip eversion, following condition is seen. Which of the following is not true about the given image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Extravasation is not that common
Sol :  
The shown condition is mucocele of the lip
•	It is retention cyst of minor salivary glands
•	Most common site: Lower lip
•	Upon examination: Soft and cystic mass of bluish colour.
•	It is brilliantly transilluminant
•	Extravasation is very common
•	Treatment is surgical excision

questions.text: A trumpet blower present with left sided neck swelling. X-ray reveals following finding. Most likely diagnosis of this patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laryngoceoele

Sol : 

Laryngocoele is a air-filled cystic swelling due to dilatation of the saccule.
Aquired laryngocele: Increased pressure in the laryngeal lumen wind instrument player)
Laryngopyocele: infected laryngocele
It may be:

Internal: confined within the larynx and look like distension of false cord and aryepiglottic fold.
External - saccule herniates through the thyroid membrane and presents in neck.
Mixed in which both internal and external components are seen.
Clinical Feature

Hoarseness, cough and if large in size then present with airway obstruction.
It is reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva.
Diagnosis

Made by indirect laryngoscopy, and soft tissue AP and lateral vies of neck with Valsalva.


Treatment

Internal laryngocele: treated by endoscopic laser surgery
External laryngocele: transcervical approach

questions.text: Pharyngeal pouch is located between:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus

Sol : 

Pharyngeal pouch also known as hypopharyngeal diverticulum or Zenker's diverticulum.
It is a pulsion diverticulum in which pharyngeal mucosa herniates through the Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle).
Inferior constrictor muscle has two parts-thyropharyngeus muscle with oblique fibres and cricopharyngeus muscle with transverse fibres.

choices.text: Palatal Palsy, Temporo-parietal pain, Conductive Hearing Loss
Palatal Palsy, Temporo-parietal pain, Sensorineural Hearing Loss
Palatal Palsy, Retro-orbital pain, Conductive Hearing Loss

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Trotter's Triad
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Palatal Palsy, Temporo-parietal pain, Conductive Hearing Loss
Sol :  
•	Trotter’s triad is a unique symptom complex associated with infiltrative malignant tumours invading the lateral wall of nasopharynx or a lesion arising in the region of sinus of Morgagni.
•	Pathognomonic features in sequential order include ipsilateral conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube block, trigeminal nerve neuralgia affecting the mandibular division initially and anaesthesia later, secondary to its invasion in foramen ovale, and palatal asymmetry owing to ipsilateral direct infiltration of levator palatini muscles.

questions.text: A child presents with history of foreign body ingestion.The X-ray picture is given in the image. What is the possible site of foreign body impaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Oesophagus

Sol :

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Diphtheric Tonsillitis

Sol : 

The whitish membrane extending beyond the tonsil, enlarges lymph nodes and bleed on removal go in favor of Diphtheria

questions.text: In a patient with Hypopharyngeal CA, > 3 cm, with the ipsilateral involvement and no extension to opposite side. Grading would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

T3

Sol :

questions.text: A 6-year-old ramu has inspiratory stridor. All the following disorders cause inspiratory stridor except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (b)

Acute bronchospasm
Reference –  Read the text below
Sol:
•	Stridor is a symptom, not a diagnosis or disease, and the underlying cause must be determined. Stridor may be inspiratory, expiratory, or biphasic depending on its timing in the respiratory cycle.
•	Inspiratory stridor suggests an extrathoracic lesion (eg, laryngeal, nasal, pharyngeal).
•	Expiratory stridor implies an intrathoracic lesion (eg, tracheal, bronchial). Biphasic stridor suggests a subglottic or glottic anomaly.Inspiratory stridor is the hallmark of upper airway obstruction.
•	Among the disorders that can involve the upper airway and cause stridor are epiglottitis, infectious laryngotracheitis,angioneurotic edema, and foreign- body aspiration. In contrast, acute bronchospasm prolongs the expiratory phase of respiration and causes predominantly expiratory wheezing rather than inspiratory stridor.

choices.text: Nasopharyngeal swab for SARS CoV2 testing
Oropharyngeal swab for rapid antigen test

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient came to OPD in April 2020, with symptoms of cold and cough associated with loss of smell and taste. Next step in management:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nasopharyngeal swab for SARS CoV2 testing
Sol :  

•	During outbreak of covid, with symptoms of common colds, loss of smell and taste, raises suspicion of covid
•	RT-PCR is advised with Nasopharyngeal swab.

questions.text: Upon endoscopy, the following structure is seen which is marked with arrow. Name this structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fossa of rosenmuller

Sol : 

Eustachian tube opening present on the lateral wall of nasopharynx, situated 1.25 cm behind the posterior end of inferior turbinate.
An elevation known as Torus tubarius raised by the cartilage of the tube bound the tube above and behind.
Above and behind the tubal elevation is a recess called fossa of Rosenmüller.
Fossa of Rosenmüller is the commonest site for origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
From lower end of torus tubarius a ridge extends to the lateral pharyngeal wall and is called salpingopharyngeal fold. It is raised by corresponding muscle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with recurrent sinusitis. Surgical intervention is advised for this patient. Which of the following is gold standard investigation before endoscopic surgery like functional endoscopic sinus surgery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CT scan
Sol :  

•	CT scan of sinuses will tell the extent of disease, predisposing structural abnormalities, amount of destruction of bony walls and any extension to orbit and cranial cavity.
•	Investigation of choice for diagnosis of sinusitis is also CT scan.

questions.text: In view of mucormycosis - the least possible cause could be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Broad spectrum antibiotics
Sol :  

•	Rhinocerebral mucormycosis is a rare opportunistic infection of the sinuses, nasal passages, oral cavity, and brain caused by saprophytic fungi. The infection can rapidly result in death. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis commonly affects individuals with diabetes and those in immunocompromised states.
•	Saprophytic aerobic fungi of the class Phycomycetes (order Mucorales) cause rhinocerebral mucormycosis, also known as phycomycosis. The 3 genera responsible for most cases are Rhizopus, Absidia, and Mucor
Treatment of rhinocerebral mucormycosis includes the following:
•	Reversing underlying immunocompromised states
•	Administering systemic antifungals
•	Performing urgent surgical debridement

Correcting hypoxia, acidosis, hyperglycemia, and electrolyte abnormalities is critical to the successful management of this condition.
Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (GCSF) can be administered to reconstitute host defenses and to enhance leukocytosis.
Dexamethasone has been used to treat brain edema. 
Hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) therapy has been used in an attempt to control the infection. 
Amphotericin B is the only reliable systemic antifungal agent approved for the treatment of mucormycosis, and the highest possible tissue levels should be achieved.

questions.text: External contour of nose is maintained by.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Bony Upper 1/3 and cartilaginous lower 2/3

Sol : 

External contour of nose is maintained by  bony Upper 1/3 and cartilaginous lower 2/3

questions.text: A 14 year old boy presents with reddish nasal mass, profuse epistaxis & Proptosis. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Juvenile nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma
Sol :  

•	Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. It originates from sphenopalatine foramen. 
•	It’s a highly vascular tumour. CECT scan shows Hollman Miller ( =Antral) sign. Surgery is treatment of choice. 
•	Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss. 
•	Pre-op Estrogen, Flutamide ( androgen antagonist) are helpful in reducing blood loss.
•	Debulking or biopsy of this tumour is never done as it is a highly vascular tumour.
•	Tumours confined to nasopharynx can be approached through Wilson’s transpalatal approach. But tumours extending to cheek would need trans- maxillary approach using weber fergusson incision.

choices.text: Kiesselbach’s plexus is supplied mainly by sphenopalatine artery.
It is present on lateral wall of nose
It is present in the posterior part of nasal cavity
It is rare site of epistaxis

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Little's area
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Keisselbach's plexus is suuplied mainly by sphenopalatine artery.

Sol : 

Keisselbach’s plexus is made by superior labial, greater palatine, sphenopalatine and anterior ethmoidal arteries.
It is present on anterior part of septum

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with the arrow:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Epiglottis

Sol :

choices.text: Close reduction after 7 days once oedem subside.
Closed reduction and swelling automatically decreased

questions.text: A boy fell down while playing and the nose is deviated but septum was normal. Next step in management:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Close reduction after 7 days once oedem subside.

Sol : 

Fractures of nasal septum are the most common fracture over face. The amplitude of force can be from front or below.
Nasal bone fracture, are also common. Traumatic forces may act from the front or side depend on amplitude.
Types

Depressed: Due to frontal blow.
Angulated: Due to lateral blow.
Symptoms

Swelling within few hours of trauma
Tenderness
Nasal deformity
Epistaxis
Nasal obstruction - due to hematoma or septal injury
Periorbital ecchymosis
Diagnosis

On physical examination
X-rays should include Waters view, right and left lateral views and occlusal view
Treatment

Simple fractures without displacement need no treatment
Others-may  require closed or open reduction
Presence of edema interferes with accurate reduction by closed methods.
So, best time me to reduce fracture is before the appearance of oedema, or after it has subsided, which is usually in 5-7 days.

questions.text: Syphilis affect which part of nasal septum:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bony
Sol :  
Nasal syphilis can be congenital or acquired.
Acquired syphilis is the more common one and itoccurs as:
Primary: Rare form. Manifest as primary chancre of vestibule
Secondary: Manifest as simple rhinitis with crusting and fissuring of nasal vestibule
Tertiary: In this stage nose is commonly involved and commonly manifest as formation of gumma on nasal septum. Later this septum is destroyed also in bony and cartilaginous part both → lead to septal perforation.
Also has foul odor nasal discharge with crust.
Can lead to septal collapse and nose deformity
Congenital syphilis ocurs in two forms: early and late form:
Early form: Seen in first 3 months of life and manifest as snuffles, followed by purulent discharge
Late form: Manifest around puberty. Presents as tertiary stage of acquired syphilis.
Treatment:
DOC: Benzathine penicillin 2.4 MU intramuscular weekly for 3 weeks.

questions.text: Lymphoid tissue related with adenoids is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Luschka’s tonsil. .
Sol:
Adenoids
•	Lymphoid tissue (Luschka’s tonsil) is found just behind the pharyngeal recess, where the roof of the nasopharynx joins the upper posterior wall.
•	The enlargement of this lymphoid tissue is commonly referred to as the adenoids. 
•	Arterial Supply: ascending pharyngeal artery from the external carotid artery, minor branches from internal maxillary artery (pharyngeal branch) and facial arteries (ascending palatine artery)
•	Venous Drainage: pharyngeal veins → facial and internal jugular vein

choices.text: It is benign but has malignant potential
It is malignant and do not metastasize

questions.text: True about inverted papilloma arising from lateral wall of nose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It is benign but has malignant potential
Sol :  

•	Inverted papilloma, which arises from the mucosa of lateral wall of nose, most frequently affects males in the age group of 30-5O years. 
•	It is benign but has malignant potential
•	Only 10-15% are associated with malignancy. 
•	Treatment is complete excision which amounts to medial maxillectomy. 
•	Post-operative radiotherapy is not necessary.

choices.text: Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel
Shift patient to OT and cautery.
Use hemostatic agents do 3 to 4 gargles per day

questions.text: A Child underwent tonsillectomy and after surgery shifted to recovery room where he started bleeding and on examination a clot was seen at the site of surgery. Next step in management will be ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Primary haemorrhage. 
•	Occurs at the time of operation.
•	It can be controlled by pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Reactionary haemorrhage. 
•	Occurs within a period of 24 h and can be controlled by simple measures such as removal of the clot, application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
•	Presence of a clot prevents the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle on the vessels which pass through it (compare postpartum uterine bleeding).
Secondary haemorrhage. 
•	Usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative day. 
•	It is the result of sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.
